summary: This is a letter motion from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, seeking to quash a subpoena issued by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team to the administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP). The government argues the subpoena fails to meet the legal standards for relevance, admissibility, and specificity, and constitutes a fishing expedition.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (S2 20 Cr. 330) who issued the subpoena to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program that the government is seeking to quash.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom this government motion is addressed.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this letter motion.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant accused of crimes against the 'Minor Victims,' who are witnesses in the case and claimants in the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.
Witness-3 is one of the individuals referenced as a 'Minor Victim' in the context of the case and the EVCP, though the court ordered they not be referenced at trial as a victim.

events.title: Pre-trial Conference
events.description: A conference where the defense sought to preclude the government from arguing that the Minor Victims' settlements with the EVCP endorse their claims, to which the court and government agreed.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office is moving to quash Ghislaine Maxwell's subpoena for records from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, arguing it fails the legal standard from United States v. Nixon.
The subpoena sought four categories: payment records to victims, release forms, all material submitted by victims to the EVCP, and communications between the EVCP and victims/counsel.
The government argues the information is either already in the defense's possession, not relevant/admissible, or the request is a 'fishing expedition' that would confuse the jury under Rule 403.
The government notes that at least two victims expected to file submissions regarding the subpoena.
The document references 'Minor Victims' and 'Witness-3' as claimants/witnesses, acknowledging a court order that Witness-3 should not be referenced at trial as a victim.
